0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• routine production of oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV) has been discontinued in the United States; an emergency stockpile is maintained in the event of a poliovirus outbreak
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: (mass vaccination for outbreak control) 0.5 mL ORALLY x 1 dose

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• not recommended in infants less than 6 weeks of age
  • routine production of oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV) has been discontinued in the United States; an emergency stockpile is maintained in the event of a poliovirus outbreak
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: (mass vaccination for outbreak control) 0.5 mL ORALLY x 1 dose

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• fever or severe respiratory infection
  • hypersensitivity to vaccine components
  • immunodefiency disorders or altered immune systems
  • household contacts of immunodeficient individuals
  • severe viral infection (diarrhea, vomiting)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concurrent administration of cholera vaccine, typhoid vaccine, or plague vaccine
  • elderly patients
  • hypersensitivity to neomycin or streptomycin
  • IM injections, especially antibiotics, should be avoided for 30-60 days; increased risk of paralytic poliomyelitis
  • inadvertent OPV vaccine to household contact of immunosuppressed person; avoid close contact for 4-6 weeks after vaccination
  • pregnancy

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Other:Fever
Serious
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (rare)
  • Neurologic:Guillain-Barr syndrome, Association with vaccine unlikely, Paralytic poliomyelitis, vaccine-associated, acute (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: OPV induces intestinal immunity against poliovirus reinfection, which explains its effectiveness in controlling the wild-type poliovirus circulation . In addition, OPV persists in the pharynx for 1 to 2 weeks and is excreted in the feces for several weeks or longer after administration . Consequently, the vaccine virus can be transmitted to contacts, resulting in their immunization . However, in rare cases vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) can occur in these contacts as well as in those who are vaccinated .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
General Information
  • do not administer parentally
  • remove the protective cap off the Dispette(R); squeeze the Dispette(R) to expel the contents into the vaccinee's mouth

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid close contact with immunosuppressed individuals for 4 to 6 weeks after vaccination.
  • Tell patient to avoid other vaccines during the polio vaccination series, unless approved by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause fever.
  • Patient should not have IM injections, especially antibiotics, for up to 60 days after vaccination, as this increases patient risk of developing paralytic poliomyelitis.
